parts: Name these structures. A National Park in Hawaii named after these structures closed in 2018 when one of them named Kilauea [kil-ah-WAY-ah] erupted, creating a dangerous lava flow.

This deepest lake in the US was created by the eruption of Mount Mazama around 7,700 years ago and names Oregon’s only National Park. This lake is noted for its strikingly blue surface and contains Wizard Island.
The 1980 eruption of this volcano was the deadliest volcano-related event in United States history. Due to its ash fall, Interstate 90 between Seattle and Spokane was closed for more than a week.
Name this Irish poet of “Digging” and a poem about the death of his brother, “Mid-Term Break.”
Heaney created a notable translation of this Old English poem about the title Geatish [yea-att-ish] warrior’s defeat of the monstrous Grendel.

In his poem “Death of a Naturalist,” Heaney described these creatures as “great slime kings.” In another work, these creatures are represented by the chorus’s repetition of the phrase “brekekekex koax koax.”
Name these people who fought amongst themselves in the Musket Wars. A leader of these people named Hone Heke chopped down a flagstaff, sparking a conflict with the British.

The Maori are the indigenous people of this Pacific island country. A British governor of this country named William Hobson negotiated with the Maori and moved this country’s capital from Auckland to Wellington.

Hobson negotiated this peace treaty with the Maori, which forced them to accept British colonial rule. Despite this treaty’s promise to give the Maori continued sovereignty over their land, a clause in it allowed for British purchase of their land at any time.
The 47th item in Murray’s catalogue of Antonio Rosetti’s chamber pieces is a duet for two of these instruments. Jean Sibelius’s Opus 47 is a concerto for this highest-pitched string instrument.

This composer’s Opus 47 is his ninth violin sonata, originally dedicated to George Bridgetower, which was nicknamed “Kreutzer” [kroitser]. 19th century violinist Joseph Joachim [yo-ah-KEEM] revived interest in this composer’s D major violin concerto.

In the sixth edition of Ludwig von Köchel’s [KUR-shull’s] catalog of Mozart’s works, he assigned “47e” to a song with this title. Beethoven famously used the text from a Friedrich Schiller poem with this title in the finale of his choral ninth symphony.

answers: [10] A Maltese fort named for this patron saint of sailors defended the island against an Ottoman invasion in 1565. This saint’s namesake “fire” is a nautical weather phenomenon involving plasma being generated in an electric field. ANSWER: Saint Elmo [accept Erasmus of Formia]
World War II [prompt on World War]
parts: A Maltese fort named for this patron saint of sailors defended the island against an Ottoman invasion in 1565. This saint’s namesake “fire” is a nautical weather phenomenon involving plasma being generated in an electric field.
During the siege of Malta in this war, Nazi German and Italian air forces sought to prevent Allied ships from reaching the island.

After gaining independence from the UK, Malta sought closer relations with this man, who would later describe his political philosophy in The Green Book. This man, who is generally thought to have ordered the Lockerbie bombing, took power from King Idris I.

Name this Fox reality TV series in which competitors battle to win a head chef’s position. Particularly strong contestants on this show earn black jackets, and insults given by a figure in this show include “donkey”, “doughnut”, and “jacked-up cavewoman.”
Hell’s Kitchen stars this famously temperamental British chef, who has also starred in shows like Kitchen Nightmares and MasterChef.

This iconic Season 10 winner of Hell’s Kitchen served as the sous-chef for the red team for season 15, and 17 through 20. She has served as head chef of Gordon Ramsay Steak and Gordon Ramsay Burger in Las Vegas.
Name this short story where a fired servant strips an old woman of her kimono at the namesake gate in Kyoto.
“Rashomon” is a short story by this masterful short story author who names a Japanese literary prize presented semi-annually.
In another Akutagawa story, “In a Grove,” a woodcutter, a thief, and the murdered man himself contradict each other on how one of these katana-wielding Japanese warriors was killed.
Name this set of dietary laws, mostly deriving from the books of Leviticus and Deuteronomy.
Kosher laws prohibit the eating of the flesh of this unclean animal because, although it has cloven hooves, it does not ruminate. The meat of this animal is often eaten as pork or bacon.
This term describes the proper way to slaughter animals in accordance with kosher laws. People who perform this practice are known as shochet [shaw-het].

answers: pH [accept power of hydrogen or potential for hydrogen]

autoionization of water [or dissociation of water or self-ionization of water; accept descriptive answers such as forming hydronium and hydroxide ions or water reacting with itself; accept H2O in place of “water” or H3O+ in place of “hydronium” or OH- in place of “hydroxide”; prompt on descriptive answers involving reaction of water or splitting of water]
parts: Name this quantity, a measure of the concentration of hydrogen ions in a solution. At 25 degrees Celsius, water has a value of 7 for this quantity, making it neither acidic or basic.
The pH of one of these systems can be calculated using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation. The capacity of these systems is symbolized beta and is generally 1 near its pKa [P-K-A].

The calculation of the pH of a buffer solution using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation assumes that this reaction is negligible compared to the dissociation of acid. The equilibrium constant for this reaction at 298 Kelvin is 10 to the negative 14th power.

answers: cations [accept cation exchange capacity CEC, prompt on ions, do not accept or prompt on “anions” or “anion exchange capacity”]
parts: Name this material that is commonly used to grow plants. This material is made of a mixture of sand, silt, and clay.
Soil is classified into these parallel layers that contain differing biological and chemical properties. The topmost of these layers is the “O” type and contains organic matter.
Soils high in an “exchange capacity” named for these chemical species are easily able to swap toxic molecules of these species. The nutrients potassium and calcium are examples of these species.

Name this medieval monk who formulated an ontological argument for God’s existence. This man argued that because God is said to be the greatest possible thing, and because existence would make any good thing better, God must exist.
William Paley, another thinker who stated a proof of God, compared God to a maker of these timekeeping devices worn on the wrist or in the pocket.

In his namesake “wager,” this philosopher argued that we should believe in God because if God does exist, refusing to believe in him results in eternal pain, while believing in him results in eternal happiness.

answers: wave-particle duality [accept answers involving waves and particles; prompt on duality]
Louis de Broglie [de-BROY] [accept de Broglie wavelength]
parts: Name this concept in quantum mechanics that was used by Albert Einstein to explain the photoelectric effect.

Wave-particle duality was expanded upon by this physicist, who along with Bohm, proposed the pilot-wave theory to explain it. This physicist’s namesake wavelength is equal to Planck’s constant divided by momentum.

The Davisson-Germer experiment demonstrated the wave-particle duality of these elementary particles. These negatively-charged particles were ejected from the surface of a metal in the photoelectric effect.

answers: Crown of the Kingdom of Poland and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania [or Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth; accept answers involving Poland]
parts: Name this officer who was killed during the 1779 siege of Savannah. This noble worked with the Hungarian Michael Kovats to form and train the American cavalry force during the Revolutionary War.
Pulaski was a cavalry officer from this country, which had recently undergone its first partition when the Revolutionary War broke out.

Pulaski’s fellow countryman Thaddeus Kosciusko [koas-COOS-koh] led the effort to fortify the Continental Army before this “turning point of the Revolution.” Benedict Arnold rose to fame after this 1777 battle in upstate New York.
Dinesen wrote Out of Africa about her experience living on a coffee plantation in this African country. Ngugi wa Thiong’o wrote Petals of Blood, a novel set in this former British colony.
Dinesen earlier wrote seven tales titled for being in this genre exemplified by The Castle of Otranto, which often features intimidating castles and paranormal activity.
Dinesen was from this country. This home of Hans Christian Andersen features a statue of his character The Little Mermaid in its capital of Copenhagen.
Name this art patron who commissioned the painting of Time Transfixed. This man stares into a mirror that reflects the back of his head in Not to be Reproduced.

James was a patron of this painter of Time Transfixed and Not to be Reproduced. This Belgian surrealist’s painting The Treachery of Images consists of a picture of a pipe accompanied by the words “this is not a pipe.”

Magritte’s painting The Son of Man features a man in a bowler hat whose face is eclipsed by one of these fruits. The Fall of Man, a painting by Titian, centers on Adam and Eve being tempted to eat one of these fruits.

answers: Nobody [accept No One or other reasonable equivalents; accept Outis]
parts: Polyphemos was one of these giant figures from Greek mythology. Brontes, Steropes, and Arges were another three of these figures.

Many classical writers described Polyphemos’s love for a nymph with this name, whose lover Acis was killed by Polyphemos. Pygmalion sculpted an ivory statue with this name which then proceeded to come to life.
Odysseus introduced himself to Polyphemos with this name. As a result, Polyphemos was unable to call for help from the other Cyclopes.

answers: Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes
slaves [accept enslaved people or Slave Play]
parts: This two-part Tony Kushner play features the AIDS-stricken former drag queen Prior Walter’s visit from the title religious figures.
This one-act Edward Albee play features the probably-gay drag queen Jerry, who impales himself on Peter’s knife at the end.

The gay American playwright Jeremy O. Harris wrote a play titled for these people which features the gay couple Dustin and Gary. A Leslie Fiedler essay analyzes the homoerotic relationship between Huckleberry Finn and a boy who escapes from this position, Jim.
Name this protein that is found in the extracellular matrix and connective tissue. The amino acid hydroxyproline is a major component of this protein.
Approximately one-third of collagen consists of this amino acid. This amino acid is notably the only achiral amino acid and acts as a neurotransmitter.
This water-soluble vitamin is a cofactor in the synthesis of collagen. This vitamin is commonly found in citrus fruits and its deficiency causes scurvy.

answers: France [or French Republic or République française]
parts: Name this architect who was one of the pioneers of modernism. This architect was commissioned by Jawaharlal Nehru to design the Indian city of Chandigarh in 1950.

The Unité d'Habitation de Marseilles [yoo-NEE-tay dah-bee-tah-SYOAN day MAR-say], which is located in this country, exemplifies Le Corbusier's idea that “a house is a machine for living in.” Le Corbusier also designed the Villa Savoye on the outskirts of this country’s capital, Paris.

Both the Villa Savoye and the Unité d'Habitation were constructed using the technique of béton brut, which involves leaving this material unfinished after it is cast. Moshe Safdie designed a Montreal apartment complex primarily using this material.
Name this cash crop. The port of Santos is a major exporter of this crop, which comes in Arabica and Robusta varieties.

The Coffee with Milk Period ended with the rise of populist president Getulio Vargas, who created a state monopoly for oil under this corporation. Massive corruption in this organization was investigated in Operation Car Wash.

Vargas’s second presidency ended in his suicide at the Catete Palace in this city, which was the capital of Brazil until it was moved to Brasilia. Vargas designed a road in this city that runs near its famous Christ the Redeemer Statue and Sugarloaf Mountain.
